W. R. D. Bandaranaike|Solomon Bandaranaike]]
|2 October 1940|26 September 1959|end=died}} | relations = {{Unbulleted list|[[Ratwatte family]]|[[Bandaranaike family]]}} | children = {{Dotlist|[[Sunethra Bandaranaike|Sunethra]]|[[Chandrika Kumaratunga|Chandrika]]|[[Anura Bandaranaike|Anura]]}} | parents = {{Unbulleted list|[[Barnes Ratwatte]]|Rosalind Kumarihamy}} | residence = {{Unbulleted list|[[Tintagel (Residence)|Tintagel]]|[[Horagolla Walauwa]]}} | education = {{Unbulleted list|Ferguson High School, Ratnapura|[[St Bridget's Convent, Colombo]]}} | occupation = {{Dotlist|[[Social worker]]|politician|diplomat|stateswoman}} | signature = }} '''Sirima Ratwatte Dias Bandaranaike''' ({{lang-si|සිරිමා රත්වත්තේ ඩයස් බණ්ඩාරනායක}}, {{lang-ta|சிறிமா ரத்வத்தே டயஸ் பண்டாரநாயக்கே}}; 17 April 1916 – 10 October 2000), commonly known as '''Sirimavo Bandaranaike'''{{NoteTag|The suffix "''vo''" denotes respect; '''Mrs Bandaranaike''', '''Mrs B''', or '''Mathini'''{{sfn|Rettie|2000}}}}, was a [[Sri Lanka]]n stateswoman. She became the world's first definitive non-hereditary [[List of elected and appointed female heads of state and government|female head of state or government]] when she was elected [[Prime Minister of Sri Lanka]] in 1960. She served three terms: 1960–1965, 1970–1977 and 1994–2000. Born into an aristocratic [[Kandyan]] family, Sirimavo Bandaranaike was educated in Catholic, English-speaking schools, though in fact she was Buddhist and spoke Sinhala as well as English. On graduating from secondary school, she worked in various social programmes before marrying and raising a family. Playing hostess to her husband [[S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike]], who was involved in politics and later became Prime Minister, she gained his trust as an informal advisor. Her work in a voluntary social improvement projects focused on improving the lives of village women and girls. Following her husband’s assassination in 1959, Sirimavo Bandaranaike entered politics and in 1960 became the first elected woman to serve as Prime Minister of a country. Bandaranaike attempted to reform the former British Colony of Ceylon into a [[socialist]] republic by nationalizing organizations in the banking, education, industry, media and trade sectors. Changing the administrative language from English to Sinhala, she acerbated discontent among the [[Indian Tamils of Sri Lanka|estate Tamils]], who had become stateless under the [[Ceylon Citizenship Act|Citizenship Act of 1948]]. During Bandaranaike's first two terms as Prime Minister, the country was plagued by high inflation and taxes, a dependence on food imports to feed the populace, high unemployment, and polarization between the Sinhalese and Tamil populations. Surviving an attempted [[coup d'état]] in 1962, as well as a 1971 [[insurrection]] of radical youths, in 1972 she led the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] to draft a new constitution and form a republic. In 1975, Bandaranaike created what would eventually become the Sri Lankan [[Ministry of Women and Child Affairs]], also appointing the first woman to serve in the Sri Lankan Cabinet. Bandaranaike's tenure was marked by inadequate economic development at the national level, while simultaneously successfully navigating the polarized [[Cold War]] factions through her leadership in the [[Non-Aligned Movement|Non-Aligned Nations]]. Ousted from power in the 1977 elections, Bandaranaike was stripped of her civil rights in 1980 and barred from government for seven years. Her successors initially improved the domestic economy, but failing to address social issues, led the country into a protracted [[Sri Lankan Civil War|civil war]]. When she returned to party leadership in 1986, Bandaranaike opposed the government solution of allowing the [[Indian Peace Keeping Force]] to intervene in the dispute, believing it violated Sri Lankan sovereignty. Failing to win the office of President in 1988, she served as Leader of the Opposition in the legislature from 1989 to 1994. When her daughter won the presidential election that year, Bandaranaike was appointed to her third term as Prime Minister and served until her retirement in 2000, two months prior to her death. == Early life (1916–1940) == [[Image:Mahawalatenna.JPG|thumb|left|300px|The Mahawalatenne family, including Mahawalatenne Rate Mahattaya (back row right) and Agnes Mahawalatenne (née Ellawala, front row right), the maternal grandparents of Sirima Ratwatte.]] Bandaranaike was born Sirima Ratwatte on 17 April 1916 at the Ellawala Walawwa in [[Ratnapura]], in [[British Ceylon]].{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}}{{sfn|Perera|2016}} Her mother was Rosalind Hilda Mahawalatenne Kumarihamy,{{sfn|Richards|2014|p=194}}{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}} a reputed [[Ayurveda|Ayurvedic]] physician,{{sfn|Lokubandara|2005}} and her father was [[Barnes Ratwatte]], a politician. Her maternal grandfather Mahawalatenne, and later her father, served as [[Rate Mahatmaya]], a native headman, of [[Balangoda]].{{sfn|Fernando|2015b}} Her father was a member of the [[Radala]], hereditary nobility from the [[Kingdom of Kandy]].{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}} Her paternal ancestry included her uncle Sir [[Cuda Ratwatte|Jayatilaka Cudah Ratwatte]], the first person from Kandy to receive a British knighthood,{{sfn|Meegama|2003|pp=57–58}}{{sfn|Ratwatte|2014}} as well as [[courtier]]s serving [[Sinhalese monarchy|Sinhalese monarchs]].{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}} One of these, Ratwatte, Dissawa of Matale, was a signatory of the 1815 [[Kandyan Convention]].{{sfn|Low|2017|p=352}} Sirima was the eldest in a family of six children.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}} She had four brothers, [[Barnes Ratwatte II|Barnes Jr.]], [[Seevali Ratwatte|Seevali]], Mackie, and [[Clifford Ratwatte|Clifford]]; and one sister, Patricia,{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} who married Colonel Edward James Divitotawela, founder of the Central Command of the [[Ceylon Army]].{{sfn|Fernando|2015b}} The family resided at the [[Walauwa|walawwa]], or colonial manor house, of Sirima's maternal grandfather Mahawalatenne, and then later at their own walawwa in Balangoda. From a young age, Sirima had access to her grandfather's vast library of literary and scientific works.{{sfn|Perera|2016}} She first attended a private kindergarten in Balangoda, moved briefly in 1923 to the [[primary school|primary classes]] of Ferguson High School in Ratnapura, and was then sent to [[boarding school]] at [[St Bridget's Convent, Colombo]].{{sfn|Perera|2016}}{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}}{{sfn|Fernando|2017}} Though her education was in the Catholic school system, Sirima remained a practicing [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] throughout her life{{sfn|Rettie|2000}}{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} and was fluent in both [[English language|English]] and [[Sinhalese language|Sinhala]].{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} After completing her schooling at age 19,{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=170}} Sirima Ratwatte became involved in social work, distributing food and medicine to jungle villages, organizing clinics and helping create rural industry to improve the living standards of village women.{{sfn|Rettie|2000}}{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} She became the treasurer of the Social Service League, serving in that capacity until 1940.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=123}} Over the next six years, she lived with her parents while they arranged her marriage.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=170}} After rejecting two suitors – a relative, and the son of the first family of Ceylon – Ratwatte's parents were contacted by a [[Matchmaking|matchmaker]] who proposed a union with [[S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike|Solomon West Ridgeway Dias (S.W.R.D.) Bandaranaike]],{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} an [[University of Oxford|Oxford]]-educated lawyer-turned-politician, who was at the time [[Second Board of Ministers of Ceylon|Minister of Local Administration]] in the [[State Council of Ceylon]].{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} Initially, S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike was not considered to be from an "acceptable" family, as the Ratwattes were an aristocratic Kandyan family, which had inherited their service to the traditional royal family, while the Bandaranaikes were a wealthy family from the low-country, which had been in service of the colonial rulers for centuries.{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} Astrologers reported their horoscopes were compatible, the benefits of uniting the families was weighed, and approval was given by the Ratwatte family.{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} The couple, who had previously met, were in agreement with the choice.{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=170–171}} == Raising a family, social work (1940–1959) == [[File:Horagolla Walauwa, Atthanagalla, Sri Lanka.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Horagolla Walauwa|Horagolla Walawwa]], the Bandaranaike ancestral manor]] On 2 October 1940, Ratwatte and Bandaranaike married at the Mahawelatenne Walawwa{{sfn|Perera|2016}} in what was dubbed "the wedding of the century" by the press for its grandeur.{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}}{{sfn|''The Daily FT|2016}} The newly married couple moved into ''Wendtworth'' in Colombo's Guildford Crescent, which they rented from [[Lionel Wendt]]. Their daughters, [[Sunethra Bandaranaike|Sunethra]] (1943) and [[Chandrika Kumaratunga|Chandrika]] (1945), were born at ''Wendtworth'' where the family lived until 1946, when S.W.R.D.'s father bought them a mansion known as ''Tintagel'' at Rosmead Place in Colombo.{{sfn|Ayivan|2007|p=154}}{{sfn|Seneviratne|1975|p=121}} From this point onward, the family lived part of the year at ''Tintagel'' and part of the year at S.W.R.D.'s ancestral manor, Horagolla Walawwa.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2014}} A son, [[Anura Bandaranaike|Anura]] was born at ''Tintagel'' in 1949.{{sfn|Seneviratne|1975|p=95}} Over the next 20 years, Sirima Bandaranaike devoted most of her time to raising her family and playing hostess to her husband's many political acquaintances.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}} All three of Bandarnaike's children were educated abroad. Sunetra studied at [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], Chandrika at the [[University of Paris]], and Anura at the [[University of London]]. All would later return and serve in Sri Lanka's government.{{sfn|Skard|2015|p=15}} In 1941 Bandaranaike joined the ''[[Lanka Mahila Samiti]]'', the country's largest women's voluntary organization. She participated in many of the social projects initiated byr the ''Mahila Samiti'' for the empowerment of rural women and disaster relief.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}}{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=123}} One of her first projects was an agricultural programme to meet food production shortages. Her first office, as secretary of the organization, involved meeting with farming experts to develop new methods for producing yields of rice crops.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=123}} Over time, Bandaranaike served as the treasurer, vice president, and eventually president of ''Mahila Samiti'', focusing on issues of girl's education, women's political rights, and family planning.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}} She was also a member of the [[All Ceylon Buddhist Women's Association]], the Cancer Society, the [[Ceylon National Association for the Prevention of Tuberculosis]], and the Nurses Welfare Association.{{sfn|Seneviratne|1975|p=115}} Bandaranaike often accompanied S.W.R.D. on official trips, both locally and abroad.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=23}} She and her husband were both present after the [[psychiatric hospital]] in [[Angoda, Sri Lanka|Angoda]] was bombed by the Japanese during the [[Easter Sunday Raid]] in 1942, killing many.{{sfn|Seneviratne|1975|p=95}}{{sfn|Gunawardena|2005|p=9}} As Ceylon moved toward [[Sri Lankan independence movement|self-governing status]] in 1947, S.W.R.D. became more active in the nationalist movement. He ran for – and was elected to – the [[House of Representatives (Ceylon)|House of Representatives]] from the [[Attanagalla Electoral District]].{{sfn|Candee|1957|p=26}} He was appointed Minister of Health and served as [[Leader of the House (Sri Lanka)|Leader of the House]], but became increasingly frustrated with the inner workings and policies of the [[United National Party]].{{sfn|Rowan|1971|pp=58–59}} Though he did not encourage Bandaranaike to engage on political topics and was [[male chauvinism|dismissive]] of her in front of colleagues, S.W.R.D. came to respect her judgment.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}}{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} In 1951, she persuaded him to resign from the United National Party and establish the [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] (Freedom Party, aka SLFP).{{sfn|Rettie|2000}}{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} Bandaranaike campaigned in S.W.R.D.'s Atthanagalla constituency during the [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1952|1952 parliamentary election]], while he travelled around the country to garner support.{{sfn|Rettie|2000}} Though the Freedom Party won only nine seats during that election, S.W.R.D. was elected to Parliament{{sfn|Rettie|2000}} and became Leader of the Opposition.{{sfn|Rowan|1971|p=59}} [[File:Sirimavo Bandaranaike 1961 (cropped) 1.PNG|left|thumb|Bandaranaike, with her children Sunethra, Chandrika, and Anura]] When fresh elections were called in 1956 by Prime Minister [[John Kotelawala|Sir John Kotelawala]], S.W.R.D. sensed an opportunity and formed the [[Mahajana Eksath Peramuna (1956)|Mahajana Eksath Peramuna]] (MEP), a broad four-party coalition, to contest the [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1956|1956 elections]].{{sfn|Candee|1957|p=27}} Bandaranaike once again campaigned for her husband in Atthanagalla, in her home town of Balangoda, and in Ratnapura for the Freedom Party.{{sfn|Jensen|2008|p=140}} The Mahajana Eksath Peramuna won a landslide victory and S.W.R.D. became the Prime Minister.{{sfn|Candee|1957|p=27}} While on a state visit to [[Hari Merdeka|Malaysia on its Independence]] in 1957, the couple had to cut short their stay when they received news that Bandaranaike's father was gravely ill following a heart attack. He died two weeks after their hasty return.{{sfn|Seneviratne|1975|p=166}} Bandaranaike was at home in Rosmead Place on the morning of 25 September 1959, when [[Assassination of S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike|S.W.R.D. was shot]] multiple times by a Buddhist monk, disgruntled over what he believed to be lack of support for traditional medicine.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2014}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=169}}{{sfn|Rowan|1971|p=59}} Bandaranaike accompanied her husband to hospital where he succumbed to his wounds the following day.{{sfn|''The Daily FT''|2016}} In the political chaos that followed under the caretaker government of [[Wijeyananda Dahanayake]], many cabinet ministers were removed, and some were arrested and tried for the assassination.{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}}{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2014}} The Mahajana Eksath Peramuna coalition collapsed without S.W.R.D.'s influence, and elections were called for [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, March 1960|March 1960]] to fill the seat for the Attanagalla constituency.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}}{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} Bandaranaike reluctantly agreed to run as an independent candidate, but before the election could be held, Parliament was dissolved,{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}}{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}} and she decided not to contest the seat.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}}{{sfn|''The Times''|1960a|p=10}} When the election was held in March 1960, the United National Party won a four-seat majority over the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. [[Dudley Senanayake]], the new Prime Minister, was defeated within a month in a [[Motion of no confidence|vote of confidence]] and a second general [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, July 1960|election was called for July 1960]].{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}}{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} == Political career== [[File:Old Parliament Building Colombo.jpg|thumb|200px|The Old Parliament Building in Colombo, where the House of Representatives met beginning in 1947]] In May 1960, Bandaranaike was unanimously elected party president by the executive committee of the Freedom Party, although at the time she was still undecided about running in the July election.{{sfn|''The Times''|1960a|p=10}} Disavowing former party ties with Communists and [[Trotskyism|Trotskyists]], by early June she was campaigning with promises to carry forward the policies of her husband – in particular, establishing a republic, enacting a [[Sinhala Only Act|law to establish Sinhalese as the official language]] of the country, and recognizing the predominance of Buddhism, though tolerating the [[Indian Tamils of Sri Lanka|estate Tamils]] use of their own language and [[Hinduism|Hindu faith]].{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}}{{sfn|''The Times''|1960b|p=8}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=171-173}} Though there had been [[Sri Lankan Tamils|Tamil populations]] in the country for centuries,{{sfn|Mahadevan|2002}} the majority of the estate Tamils had been brought to Ceylon from India by the British colonisers as plantation workers. Many Ceylonese viewed them as temporary immigrants, even though they had lived for generations in Ceylon. With Ceylon's independence, the [[Ceylon Citizenship Act|Citizenship Act of 1948]] excluded these Indian Tamils from citizenship, making them stateless.{{sfn|Kanapathipillai|2009|pp=62–63}} S.W.R.D.'s policy toward the stateless Tamils had been moderate, granting some citizenship and allowing productive workers to remain. His successor, Dudley Senanayake, was the first to recommend compulsory repatriation for the population.{{sfn|Kanapathipillai|2009|p=74}} Bandaranaike toured the country and made emotional speeches, frequently bursting into tears as she pledged herself to continue her late husband's policies. Her actions earned her the title "The Weeping Widow" from her opponents.{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}}{{sfn|''BBC''|2000b}} === First female Prime Minister (1960–1965) === [[File:Sirimavo Bandaranaike 1962.png|thumb|left|150px|Bandaranaike praying in a 1962 photograph described as the "Praying Premier" by the Associated Press]] On 21 July 1960, following a landslide victory for the Freedom Party, Bandaranaike was sworn in as the first female Prime Minister in the world, as well as Minister of Defence and External Affairs.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}}{{sfn|de Alwis|2008}} As she was not an elected member of parliament at the time, but leader of the party holding the majority in parliament, the [[Soulbury Commission|constitution]] required her to become a member of Parliament within three months if she was to continue holding office as Prime Minister. To make a place for her, [[M. P. de Zoysa|Manameldura Piyadasa de Zoysa]] resigned his seat in the Senate.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}}{{sfn|''The Sunday Times''|2016}} On 5 August 1960, Governor General Goonetilleke appointed Bandaranaike to the [[Senate of Ceylon]], the upper house of Parliament.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}} Initially, she struggled to navigate the issues facing the country, relying on her cabinet member and nephew, [[Felix Dias Bandaranaike]].{{sfn|''The Times''|2000|p=23}} Opponents made dismissive comments about her "kitchen cabinet": she would continue to face similar sexism while in office.{{sfn|de Alwis|2008}} To further her husband's policy of nationalizing key sectors of the economy, Bandaranaike established a corporation with public-private shareholders, taking control of seven newspapers.{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} She nationalized banking, foreign trade, and insurance,{{sfn|de Alwis|2008}} as well as the petroleum industry. In taking over the [[Bank of Ceylon]] and establishing branches of the newly created [[People's Bank (Sri Lanka)|People's Bank]], Bandaranaike aimed to provide services to communities with no previous banking facilities, spurring local business development.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=172}} In December 1960, Bandaranaike nationalized all the [[parochial school]]s that were receiving state funding.{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}}{{sfn|''Time Magazine''|1961}} In doing so she curtailed the influence of the Catholic minority, who tended to be members of the economic and political elite, and extended the influence of Buddhist groups.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=172}}{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=124}} In January 1961, Bandaranaike implemented a law making Sinhalese the official language, replacing English. This action caused wide discontent among the more than two million [[Tamil language|Tamil-speakers]].{{sfn|Moritz|1961|p=24}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=171}} Urged on by members of the [[Illankai Tamil Arasu Kachchi|Federal Party]], a campaign of [[civil disobedience]] began in the provinces with Tamil majorities. Bandaranaike's response was to declare a [[state of emergency]] and send in troops to restore peace.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=171}} Beginning in 1961, trade unions began a series of strikes in protest to high inflation and taxes. One such strike immobilized the transport system, motivating Bandaranaike to nationalize the transport board.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}} In January 1962, conflicts erupted between the established elites: the predominantly [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] Westernized urban Christians – including large contingents of [[Burgher people|Burghers]] and Tamils – and the emerging native elite, who were predominantly [[Left-wing politics|leftist]] Sinhala-speaking Buddhists.{{sfn|Balachandran|2006}}{{sfn|Fernando|2015a}} The changes caused by Bandaranaike's policies created an immediate shift away from the [[Anglophile|Anglophilic]] class system, power structures, and governance, significantly influencing the composition of the officer corps of the civil service, armed forces, and the police.{{sfn|Balachandran|2006}} Some military officers plotted a [[1962 Ceylonese coup d'état attempt|coup d'état]], which included plans to detain Bandaranaike and her cabinet members at the [[Army Headquarters (Sri Lanka)|Army Headquarters]]. When the police official [[Stanley Senanayake]] was taken into the confidence of the coup leadership, he rushed to [[Temple Trees]] to inform Bandaranaike and other government and party officials. Immediately calling all service commanders and junior officers to an emergency meeting at the official residence, Felix Dias Bandaranaike and members of [[Committee of Imperial Defence]] (CID) began questioning the military personnel and uncovered the plot.{{sfn|Fernando|2015a}} Because the coup was aborted before it began, the trial process for the 24 accused conspirators was lengthy and complex. The retroactive ''Criminal Law Special Provision Act of 1962'', which allowed consideration of [[Hearsay|hearsay evidence]], was passed to aid in the conviction of the plotters.{{sfn|Balachandran|2006}} Though rumours circulated against Sir Oliver Goonatillake, the governor general,{{sfn|''The Hartford Courant''|1962|p=39}} there was no real evidence against him and therefore no means of prosecuting him. He was neither "removed from office nor did he resign".{{sfn|Thurai|2014}} He agreed to answer questions about his suspected involvement once he was replaced.{{sfn|''The Sydney Morning Herald''|1962|p=76}} In February [[William Gopallawa]] was appointed Governor General.{{sfn|''The Hartford Courant''|1962|p=39}} Goonatillake was escorted to the airport, left Ceylon, and went into voluntary exile.{{sfn|Fernando|2015a}} [[File:Sirimavo Bandaranaike 1961 (cropped) 4.PNG|thumb|Bandaranaike in 1961]] In an attempt to balance East-West interests and maintain neutrality, Bandaranaike strengthened the country's relationship with China, while eliminating ties with Israel. She worked to maintain good relationships with both India and Russia, while keeping ties to British interests through the [[Tea production in Sri Lanka|export of tea]] and supporting links with the World Bank. Condemning South Africa's [[apartheid]] policy, Bandaranaike appointed ambassadors to and sought relationships with other African nations.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}} In 1961, she attended both the [[Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference]] in [[London]] and the [[Non-Aligned Movement|Conference on Non-Aligned Nations]] in [[Belgrade]], [[Yugoslavia]].{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}} She was a key player in reducing tensions between India and China after their 1962 border dispute erupted into the [[Sino-Indian War]].{{sfn|''The Times''|2000|p=23}} In November and December of that year, Bandaranaike called conferences in [[Colombo]] with delegates from Burma, Cambodia, Ceylon, Ghana and the [[United Arab Republic]] to discuss the dispute. She then travelled with Ghanaian Justice Minister [[Kofi Asante Ofori-Atta|Kofi Ofori-Atta]] to India and [[Peking]], China in an attempt to broker peace.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}}{{sfn|Jackson|1963|p=7}} In January 1963, Bandaranaike and Orofi-Atta were rewarded in [[New Delhi]], when [[Jawaharlal Nehru]], the [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]], agreed to make a motion in the Indian Parliament recommending the settlement Bandaranaike had advocated for.{{sfn|Jackson|1963|p=7}} At home, difficulties were mounting. Despite her success abroad, Bandaranaike was criticized for her ties with China and lack of economic development policies. Tensions were still high over the government's apparent favouritism of Sinhala-speaking Ceylonese Buddhists. The import-export imbalance, compounded by inflation, was impacting the buying power of middle- and lower-class citizens. In the mid-year by-election, although Bandaranaike held a majority, the United National Party made gains, indicating that her support was slipping.{{sfn|Bradsher|1962|p=5}}{{sfn|''The News-Press''|1963|p=2}} Lack of support for austerity measures, specifically the inability to import adequate rice – the main dietary staple – caused the resignation of Minister Felix Dias Bandaranaike.{{sfn|Bradsher|1962|p=5}}{{sfn|''The Standard-Speaker''|1962|p=23}} Other cabinet ministers were reassigned in an attempt to stem the drift toward Soviet trade partnerships, which had gained ground after the creation of the [[Ceylon Petroleum Corporation]].{{sfn|Peiris|1963|p=13}} The Petroleum Corporation had been launched in 1961 to bypass the monopolistic pricing imposed on Middle Eastern oil imports, allowing Ceylon to import oil from the United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union. Some of the storage facilities of western oil operatives were co-opted with a compensation agreement, but continuing disputes over non-payment resulted in suspension of foreign aid from the United States in February 1963. In reaction to the suspension of aid, the Parliament passed the ''Ceylon Petroleum Corporation Amendment Act'' nationalizing all distribution, import-export, sales and supply of most oil products in the country, from January 1964.{{sfn|Kodikara|1973|p=1126}} Also in 1964, Bandaranaike's government abolished the independent [[Ceylon Civil Service]] and replaced it with the [[Sri Lankan Administrative Service|Ceylon Administrative Service]], which was subject to government influence.{{sfn|DeVotta|2017|p=11}} When the United Left Front coalition between the [[Communist Party of Sri Lanka|Communist]], [[Mahajana Eksath Peramuna|Revolutionary Socialist]] and [[Lanka Sama Samaja Party|Trotskyist]] Parties was formed in late 1963,{{sfn|Bradsher|1963|p=4}} Bandaranaike moved left to try to gain their support.{{sfn|Peiris|1964a|p=17}} In February 1964, Chinese Premier [[Zhou Enlai]] visited Bandaranaike in Ceylon with offers of aid, gifts of rice and textiles, and discussions to extend trade.{{sfn|''The Calgary Herald''|1964|p=5}} The two also discussed the Sino-Indian border dispute and nuclear disarmament.{{sfn|Kodikara|1973|p=1128}} The ties with China were attractive, as Bandaranaike's recent formal recognition of [[East Germany]] had eliminated incoming aid from [[West Germany]]{{sfn|''The Calgary Herald''|1964|p=5}} and her nationalization of the insurance industry had impacted her relationships with Australia, Britain and Canada.{{sfn|Peiris|1964b|p=21}} In preparation for the second Non-Aligned Conference, Bandaranaike hosted Presidents [[Josip Broz Tito|Tito]] and [[Gamal Abdel Nasser|Nassar]] in Colombo in March 1964,{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}} but continued domestic unrest caused her to suspend parliamentary sessions until July. In the interim, she entered into a coalition with the United Left Front and was able to shore up her majority, though only by a margin of three seats.{{sfn|Peiris|1964a|p=17}} In September 1964, Bandaranaike led a delegation to India to discuss the [[repatriation]] of the 975,000 stateless Tamils residing in Ceylon. Along with Indian Prime Minister [[Lal Bahadur Shastri]], she ironed out the terms of the [[Srimavo-Shastri Pact]], a landmark agreement for the foreign policy of both nations.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}}{{sfn|Kanapathipillai|2009|p=91}} Under the agreement, Ceylon was to grant citizenship to 300,000 of the Tamils and their descendants while India was to repatriate 525,000 stateless Tamils. During the 15 years allotted to complete their obligations, the parties agreed to negotiate terms for the remaining 150,000.{{sfn|Kanapathipillai|2009|p=91}} In October, Bandaranaike attended and co-sponsored the Non-Aligned Conference held in Cairo.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}} In December 1964, her attempt to further nationalize the country's newspapers resulted in a campaign to remove her from office. She lost a vote of confidence by one vote, dissolved the Parliament, and called for new elections.{{sfn|Peiris|1964b|p=21}} Her political coalition was defeated in the [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1965|1965 elections]], ending her first term as Prime Minister.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}} === Leader of the opposition (1965–1970) === In the 1965 elections, Bandaranaike won a seat in the [[House of Representatives (Ceylon)|House of Representatives]] from the [[Attanagalla Electoral District]].{{sfn|Parliament of Sri Lanka|2018}}{{sfn|Fink|1965|p=7}} With her party gaining 41 seats,{{sfn|''The St. Louis Post-Dispatch''|1965|p=20A}} she became the [[Leader of the Opposition (Sri Lanka)|Leader of the Opposition]], the first woman ever to hold the post.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}}{{sfn|Skard|2015|p=14}} Dudley Senanayake was sworn in as Prime Minister on 25 March 1965.{{sfn|''The St. Louis Post-Dispatch''|1965|p=20A}} Soon after, Bandaranaike's position as a member of parliament was challenged, when allegations were made that she had accepted a bribe, in the form of a car, while in office. A committee was appointed to investigate and she was later cleared of the charge.{{sfn|Rajakaruna|1966|p=5}}{{sfn|Lelyveld|1967|p=6}} During her five year term in the opposition, she maintained her alliance with leftist parties.{{sfn|Kidron|1969|p=3}} Of the seven by-elections held between November 1966 and April 1967, six were won by the opposition under Bandaranaike's leadership.{{sfn|Lelyveld|1967|p=6}} Continued inflation, trade imbalance, unemployment, and the failure of expected foreign aid to materialize led to widespread discontent. This was further fueled by austerity measures, which reduced the weekly rice stipend.{{sfn|Nossiter|1968|p=5}} By 1969, Bandaranaike was actively campaigning to return to power.{{sfn|Sims|1969|p=57}}{{sfn|''The Evening Sun''|1969|p=4}} Among other pledges, she promised to nationalize foreign banks and the import-export industry, to establish watchgroups for monitoring business and government corruption,{{sfn|''The Honolulu Star-Bulletin''|1970|p=2}} to return to a foreign policy which leaned away from "imperialist" partners,{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=271}} and to hold a Constituent Assembly charged with drafting a new Constitution.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=268}} ===Second term (1970–1977)=== [[File:Tissa with Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike in Russia with Alexei Kosygin Premier of the Soviet Union fro.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Bandaranaike with Soviet Union Prime Minister [[Alexei Kosygin]], Senior Advisor (Foreign Affairs) to the Prime Minister [[Tissa Wijeyeratne]] and [[Anura Bandaranaike]]]] Bandaranaike regained power after the [[United Front (Sri Lanka)|United Front]] coalition between the Communist Party, the [[Lanka Sama Samaja Party]] and her own Freedom Party won the [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1970|1970 elections]] with a large majority in May 1970.{{sfn|''The Honolulu Star-Bulletin''|1970|p=2}} By July, she had convened a Constitutional Assembly to replace the British-drafted constitution with one drafted by the Ceylonese.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=268}} She introduced policies requiring that permanent secretaries in the government ministries have expertise in their division. For example, those serving in the Ministry of Housing had to be trained engineers, and those serving in the Ministry of Health, medical practitioners. All government employees were allowed to join Workers Councils and at the local level, she established People's Committees to allow input from the population at large on government administration.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=269}} The changes were intended to remove elements of [[British Empire|British colonization]] and foreign influence from the country's institutions.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}} Facing budget deficits of $195 million – caused by rising energy and food-importation costs and declining revenue from coconut, rubber and tea exports – Bandaranaike attempted to centralize the economy and implement price controls.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=321–322}}{{sfn|''The Anniston Star''|1970|p=42}} Pressed by the leftist members of her coalition to nationalize the foreign banks of British, Indian and Pakistani origin, she realized that doing so would impact the need for credit.{{sfn|''The Anniston Star''|1970|p=42}} As she had in her previous regime, she tried to balance the flow of foreign assistance from both capitalist and communist partners.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=322}} In September 1970, Bandaranaike attended the third Non-Aligned Conference in [[Lusaka]], Zambia.{{sfn|''Socialist India''|1974|p=24}} That month, she also travelled to Paris and London to discuss international trade.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|pp=270–271}} Ordering representatives of [[The Asia Foundation]] and the [[Peace Corps]] to leave the country, Bandaranaike began re-evaluating trade agreements and proposals that had been negotiated by her predecessor. She announced that her government would not recognize Israel, until the country peacefully settled its problem with its Arab neighbours. She officially granted recognition to East Germany, [[North Korea]], [[North Vietnam]], and the [[National Liberation Front of South Vietnam]].{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=271}} Bandaranaike opposed the development of an Anglo-US communications centre in the [[Indian Ocean]], maintaining that the area should be a "neutral, nuclear-free zone".{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=272}} In December, the Business Undertaking Acquisition Act was passed, allowing the state to nationalize any business with more than 100 employees. Ostensibly, the move aimed to reduce foreign control of key tea and rubber production, but it stunted both domestic and foreign investment in industry and development.{{sfn|''The Anniston Star''|1970|p=42}}{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=273}} [[File:Sirimavo Bandaranaike 1961 (cropped) 5.PNG|thumb|left|Bandaranaike and her military escort, pictured in 1961]] Despite Bandaranaike's efforts to address the country's economic problems, unemployment and inflation remained unchecked.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=274}} After just 16 months in power, Bandaranaike's government was almost toppled by the [[1971 JVP Insurrection (Sri Lanka)|1971 Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna Insurrection]] of left-wing youths. Though aware of the militant stance of the [[Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna]] (People's Liberation Front), Bandaranaike's administration initially failed to recognize them as an imminent threat, dismissing them as idealists.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|pp=274–275}} On 6 March, militants attacked the U.S. Embassy in Colombo,{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=275}} leading to the declaration of a state of emergency on 17 March. In early April, attacks on police stations evidenced a well-planned insurgency which [[Sri Lanka Army|Ceylon's small army]] was ill-equipped to handle. Calling on its allies for assistance, the government was saved largely because of Bandaranaike's neutral foreign policy. The Soviet Union sent aircraft to support the Ceylonese government; arms and equipment came from Britain, the United Arab Republic, the United States and Yugoslavia; medical supplies were provided by East and West Germany, Norway and Poland; patrol boats were sent from India;{{sfn|''The Sydney Morning Herald''|1971|p=16}} and both India and Pakistan sent troops.{{sfn|Fathers|2000}} On 1 May, Bandaranaike suspended government offensives and offered an amnesty, which resulted in thousands of surrenders. The following month a second amnesty was offered. Bandaranaike established a National Committee of Reconstruction to re-establish civil authority and provide a strategic plan for dealing with those captured or surrendered insurgents.{{sfn|''The Sydney Morning Herald''|1971|p=16}} One of the Bandaranaike's first actions after the conflict was to expel North Korean diplomats, as she suspected they had fomented the radical discontent.{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|pp=275–276}} The saying ''"She was the only man in her cabinet" –'' attributed to her political opponents in the 1960s – {{sfn|McIntyre|1967|p=227}} resurfaced during the height of the insurgency,{{sfn|Fathers|2000}} as Bandaranaike proved that she had become a "formidable political force".{{sfn|de Alwis|2008}} In May 1972, the [[Dominion of Ceylon]] was replaced by the [[Sri Lanka|Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka]] and the [[Sri Lankan Constitution of 1972|new Constitution]] was ratified.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}}{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=50}} Though the country remained within the [[Commonwealth of Nations]], [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]], was no longer recognized as its sovereign.{{sfn|''The Tampa Bay Times''|1972|p=3}} Under its terms, the Senate, suspended since 1971,{{sfn|''The Sydney Morning Herald''|1971|p=16}} was officially abolished{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}} and the new unicameral [[National State Assembly]] was created, combining the powers of the executive, judicial and legislative branches in one authority.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|pp=50–51}} The constitution recognized the supremacy of Buddhism, though it guaranteed equal protection to Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, and Islam.{{sfn|Bartholomeusz|2010|p=173}} It failed to provide a [[Bill of rights|charter of inalienable rights]],{{sfn|Bartholomeusz|2010|p=173}}{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=51}} recognized Sinhalese as the only official language,{{sfn|''The New York Times''|1972|p=3}} and contained no "elements of federalism".{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=51}} The new constitution also extended Bandaranaike's term by two years, resetting the mandated five-year term of the Prime Minister to the coincide with the creation of the republic.{{sfn|''The Playground Daily News''|1976|p=36}} These limits caused concern for various sectors of the population, specifically those who were uneasy about [[dictatorship|authoritarian rule]], and the Tamil-speaking population.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=51}} Before the month was out, the discontent escalated before leading to the passage of the Justices Commission Bill, establishing separate [[tribunal]]s to deal with the imprisoned insurgents from the previous year. Those in opposition to the tribunals argued that they were a violation of the principals of human rights.{{sfn|Monks|1972|p=6}} By July, sporadic incidents of violence were resurfacing,{{sfn|Rosenblum|1972|p=27}} and by the end of the year, a second wave of revolt was anticipated. Widespread unemployment fuelled the public's growing disillusionment with the government, in spite of land redistribution programmes enacted to establish [[Agricultural cooperative|farming cooperatives]] and limit the size of privately held lands.{{sfn|Rajakaruna|1972|p=7}} The 1973 oil crisis had a traumatic effect on the Sri Lankan economy.{{sfn|Fathers|2000}} Still dependent on foreign assistance, goods and monetary aid from Australia, Canada, China, Denmark, Hungary, and the World Bank, Bandaranaike eased the austerity programmes that limited importation of consumer goods. The United States terminated aid grants, which required no repayment, and changed to a policy of providing foreign loans.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=322–323}} Devaluation of the Sri Lankan [[Sri Lankan rupee|currency]], coupled with inflation and high taxes, slowed economic growth, consequently creating cyclical pressure to address deficits with even higher taxes and austerity measures.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=324}} Uncontrolled inflation between 1973 and 1974 led to economic uncertainty and public dissatisfaction.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=326}} In 1974, Bandaranaike forced the shut-down of the last independent newspaper group, ''[[Sun (Ceylon)|The Sun]]'', believing their criticism was fuelling unrest.{{sfn|Fathers|2000}}{{sfn|Sims|1974|p=16}} Fissures appeared in the United Front coalition, largely resulting from the Lanka Sama Samaja Party's continued influence on trade unions and threats of strike actions throughout 1974 and 1975. When newly confiscated estates were placed under the Ministry of Agriculture and Lands, controlled by the Lanka Sama Samaja Party, fears that they would unionize plantation workers led Bandaranaike to oust them from the government coalition.{{sfn|Alexander|1991|p=180}} In recognition of [[International Women's Year]] in 1975, Bandaranaike created an agency to focus on women's issues, which would later become the [[Ministry of Women and Child Affairs]]. She appointed the first woman to serve in the Sri Lankan Cabinet, [[Siva Obeyesekere]], first as First State Secretary for Health and later as Minister of Health.{{sfn|Skard|2015|p=14}} She was feted at the [[World Conference on Women, 1975|UN World Conference on Women]] hosted in Mexico City, attending as the only woman Prime Minister elected in her own right.{{sfn|de Alwis|2008}} Bandaranaike stepped into the one-year term of chair at the 5th Conference of the Non-Aligned Nations in 1976, hosting the meeting in Colombo.{{sfn|Fathers|2000}}{{sfn|Woolacott|1976|p=4}} Despite her high regard internationally, she continued to struggle domestically under allegations of corruption and nepotism, while the economy continued to decline.{{sfn|''The Playground Daily News''|1976|p=36}}{{sfn|Woolacott|1976|p=4}} In their struggle for recognition, discontented Tamils turned to [[Sri Lankan Tamil nationalism|separatism]]. In May 1976, the [[Vaddukoddai Resolution]] was adopted by the [[Tamil United Liberation Front]], calling for independent statehood and sovereign autonomy.{{sfn|''The Playground Daily News''|1976|p=36}}{{sfn|Wilson|2000|p=121}} In the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1977|1977 general election]]s, the United Front was soundly defeated, winning only six seats.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}}{{sfn|''The Baltimore Sun''|1977|p=2}} ===Party leader (1977–1988)=== Bandaranaike retained her parliamentary seat in Atthanagalla in the 1977 general elections. In November 1977, a petition challenging her position as a member of parliament was dismissed by the [[High Court of Sri Lanka|Colombo High Court]].{{sfn|''The Guardian''|1977|p=8}} In 1978, a [[Constitution of Sri Lanka|new constitution]] was ratified which replaced the British-style [[Westminster system|parliamentary system]] with a French-style [[presidential system]]. Under the constitution, the executive or President, was elected by a vote of the people to serve a six-year term. The president then chose a Prime Minister to preside over the [[Cabinet (government)|Cabinet]], who was confirmed by the legislature.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=53}} Providing a declaration of [[fundamental rights]], guaranteeing the equality of citizens for the first time,{{sfn|Omar|1996|pp=158–159}} it also recognized Tamil as a national language, though the administrative language remained Sinhala. Though aimed at appeasing Tamil separatists, the provisions did not stop the violence between Tamils and Sinhalese, resulting in the passage of the [[Prevention of Terrorism Act (Sri Lanka)|1979 Prevention of Terrorism Act]].{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=54}} In 1980, a [[Presidential Commission of Inquiry|Special Presidential Commission]] was appointed by [[J. R. Jayawardene|President J. R. Jayawardene]] to investigate allegations against Bandaranaike for abuses of power during her tenure as Prime Minister.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}} Following the submission of the report to Jayawardene, the United National Party government adopted a motion in parliament on 16 October 1980 to strip Bandaranaike and her nephew, Felix Dias Bandaranaike – who was convicted of corruption – of their civil liberties for a period of seven years.{{sfn|''The Guardian''|1980|p=7}}{{sfn|''The Los Angeles Times''|2000}}{{sfn|Ashborn|1980|p=7}} She was expelled from parliament, but maintained her role as party leader.{{sfn|Ashborn|1980|p=7}}{{sfn|''The Guardian''|1980|p=7}} The motion passed by 139 votes in favour and 18 against,{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=400}}{{sfn|''The Hartford Courant''|1980|p=C23}} easily meeting the required two-thirds threshold.{{sfn|''The Guardian''|1980|p=7}} Despite being its head, Bandaranaike was unable to campaign for the Freedom Party. As a result, her son, Anura served as the parliamentary party leader.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=53}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=400}}{{sfn|''The Age''|1986|p=6}} Under Anura the Freedom Party moved to the right, and Bandaranaike's daughter, Chandrika, withdrew, forming the [[Sri Lanka Mahajana Pakshaya|Sri Lanka People's Party]] with her husband, [[Vijaya Kumaratunga]]. The goals of the new party were related to [[rapprochement]] with the Tamils.{{sfn|Rettie|2000}} From 1980, conflict with the separatists of various competing groups, including the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam|Tamil Tigers]], [[People's Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam]], [[Tamil Eelam Liberation Army]], and the [[Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization]] became more frequent and increasingly violent.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|p=54}}{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=383}} During local election campaigning in 1981, Tamil extremists assassinated [[Arumugam Thiagarajah]], the United National Party candidate. Boycotting the 1982 presidential elections was called for by the [[Tamil United Liberation Front]] Party.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|pp=54–55}} Insurgents supported the ban, as cooperation with the government legitimized its policies and conflicted with the desire for attaining an independent Tamil state.{{sfn|Kearney|1985|p=907}} In 1983 insurgent Tamils ambushed an army patrol, killing thirteen soldiers. Retaliatory violence by Sinhalese mobs, sparked riots against non-insurgent Tamils and their property which spread from Colombo throughout the country.{{sfn|Ross|Savada|1990|pp=54–55}}{{sfn|Kearney|1985|p=908}} Jayewardene's move towards free markets and a focus on economic growth hurt Tamil farmers in the north by removing trade protections. Similarly, the policies negatively impacted not only southern Sinhalese businesses facing competition from Indian markets, but also the urban poor, whose food subsidies were greatly reduced.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=404}} Massive government spending for economic development created budget deficits and inflation, alarming the World Bank and [[International Monetary Fund]] administrators. In turn, donor agencies reduced aid to persuade the government to control spending.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=410–411}} Acceleration of the [[Mahaweli Development programme]] increased employment and stabilized the food supply,{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=429}} also reducing dependence on foreign energy supplies with the completion of four [[hydropower]]-generating facilities.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=430}} The focus on building the economy and infrastructure failed to address social issues.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=431}} For example, the rural housing initiative – which built some 100,000 new homes by 1984 – polarized communities because housing was distributed by political alliance rather than need.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=436}} Privatization of industry, after 1982, created significant gaps between the rich and poor and inflation returned, making goods hard to procure and lowering the standard of living.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=518–519}} In January 1986, Bandaranaike's civil rights were restored by a presidential decree issued by Jayewardene.{{sfn|''The Age''|1986|p=6}} The conflict between the government and the separatists, which had escalated since 1983, morphed into a [[Sri Lankan Civil War|Civil War]] by 1987.{{sfn|Samaranayaka|2008|p=326}} Jayewardene showed little sympathy for the issues of concern to the Tamils and instead blamed the unrest on left-wing factions plotting a government overthrow.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|p=526}} Breakdowns in negotiations with the rebels eventually led Jayewardene to authorize the intervention of the Indian Government. Signed in 1987, ''The [[Indo-Sri Lanka Accord]]'', laid out terms of the truce between the Sri Lankan Government and the rebels, authorizing the [[Indian Peace Keeping Force]] to occupy the country in an attempt to promote disarmament.{{sfn|Samaranayaka|2008|pp=347–349}} Bandaranaike and the Freedom Party opposed the introduction of Indian troops, believing the government had betrayed its own people by allowing India to intervene on behalf of the Tamils.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=532, 541}} As a reaction to state-sanctioned violence and their desire for nationalist focus, the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna militants re-emerged in the south.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=547–548}} Against this backdrop, Bandaranaike decided to run in the [[Sri Lankan presidential election, 1988|1988 presidential election]]. She was narrowly defeated by [[Ranasinghe Premadasa]] who succeeded Jayewardene as President.{{sfn|''The Los Angeles Times''|2000}} ===Leader of the opposition (1989–1994)=== [[File:Sirimavo Ratwatte Dias Bandaranayaka (1916-2000) (Hon.Sirimavo Bandaranaike with Hon.Lalith Athulathmudali Crop).jpg|thumb|Bandaranaike in her later years (circa 1981)]] On 6 February 1989, while campaigning for the Freedom Party in the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1989|1989 general election]], Bandaranaike survived a bombing attack. Though she was unscathed, one of her aides suffered leg injuries.{{sfn|''The Gazette''|1989|p=2}} In the final results on the 19th, the Freedom Party was defeated by the United National Party under [[Ranasinghe Premadasa]], but gained 67 seats, sufficient for Bandaranaike to take up the post of Leader of the Opposition for a second term.{{sfn|Spencer|1989|p=47}} She was successfully re-elected to parliament in the [[Gampaha Electoral District|Gampaha electoral district]].{{sfn|Government of Sri Lanka|2001|p=2}} The same year, the government crushed the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna rebels, killing some 30,000 to 70,000 of them, rather than opting for trials or imprisonment as Bandaranaike had done in 1971.{{sfn|Rettie|2000}} In 1990, when the 13-month ceasefire was broken by the Tamil Tigers, after other militias surrendered their weapons, the government decided to break off negotiations with the Tigers and employ a military solution. Anura supported the move,{{sfn|''The Daily Spectrum''|1990|p=15}} but his mother, Bandaranaike, spoke against the plan. When emergency powers were granted by the president, she demanded that the state of emergency be lifted, accusing the government of human rights abuses.{{sfn|Murdoch|1990|p=9}} During her tenure as opposition leader, she supported the impeachment of Premadasa in 1991, which was led by senior United National Party members such as [[Lalith Athulathmudali]] and [[Gamini Dissanayake]]. The impeachment failed, as Premadasa adjourned Parliament and the Speaker [[M. H. Mohamed]] dismissed the motion for impeachment, stating there were not enough signatures supporting it.{{sfn|Bandula|2013}} Bandaranaike's daughter Chandrika Kumaratunga, who had been living in self-imposed exile in London since 1988, when her husband had been assassinated, returned to Sri Lanka and rejoined the Freedom Party in 1991.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=412}} In the same year, Bandaranaike, who was increasingly impaired by arthritis, suffered a stroke.{{sfn|Dahlburg|1994|p=29}} In 1992, Premadasa Udugampola, head of the Bureau of Special Operations, was forced to retire after an international outcry over human rights abuse surfaced. Udugampola provided a written statement that the [[death squad]]s used against rebels had been backed by the government. Bandaranaike came out in support of his evidence, but Udugampola was charged for cultivating public hostility against the government.{{sfn|''The Times''|1992|p=17}} When President Premadasa was assassinated by a suicide bomber on 1 May 1993, his Prime Minister [[Dingiri Banda Wijetunga]] was sworn as acting president and nominated to complete the president's unexpired term until 2 January 1995.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=410}}{{sfn|''The Daily Sitka Sentinel''|1993|p=10}} Due to her failing health, Bandaranaike chose not to run for the presidency, but to continue as opposition leader, and Wijetunga ran unopposed. The members of Parliament were required to vote on the succession within a month.{{sfn|''The Daily Sitka Sentinel''|1993|p=10}}{{sfn|Goldenberg|1993|p=12}} Wijetunga convinced Bandaranaike's son, Anura, to defect to the United National Party and rewarded him with an appointment as Minister of Higher Education.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=411}}{{sfn|''The Guardian''|1993|p=11}} His defection left Bandaranaike and Kumaratunga in charge of the Freedom Party.{{sfn|Rettie|1993|p=8}} Due to her mother's declining health, Kumaratunga led the formation of a new coalition, the [[People's Alliance (Sri Lanka)|People's Alliance (PA)]], to contest the 1993 provincial election in the [[Western Province, Sri Lanka|Western Province of Sri Lanka]] in May. The alliance won a landslide victory, and Kumaratunga was appointed as the [[Chief Minister]] in 1993. Subsequently the coalition led by Kumaratunga also won the southern provincial council elections.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=412}} Kumaratunga led the People's Alliance campaign for the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 1994|1994 parliamentary election]], as her mother was recovering from surgery.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|pp=416–417}} The Alliance won a decisive victory, and Bandaranaike announced that Kumaratunga would become Prime Minister.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=418}} By this time Kumaratunga had also succeeded her as the leader of the Freedom Party. Mentally alert but suffering from a foot ailment and complications from [[diabetes]], Bandaranaike was confined to a wheel chair.{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2016}} Having been re-elected to parliament, she was appointed to her daughter's cabinet as a [[Minister without Portfolio]] at the swearing-in ceremony held on 19 August 1994.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|p=419}} ===Third term (1994–2000)=== In the [[Sri Lankan presidential election, 1994|presidential election]] that followed in November, Kumaratunga's main political rival, [[Gamini Dissanayake]], was assassinated two weeks before the election. His widow, [[Srima Dissanayake]], was chosen as the United National Party's presidential candidate. Kumaratunga's lead was predicted to be around a million votes even before the assassination: she won the election by a wide margin.{{sfn|Schaffer|1995|pp=422–423}} Becoming the first female [[President of Sri Lanka]], Kumaratunga appointed her mother as prime minister,{{sfn|Sebastian|1994|}} which under the terms of the 1978 constitution meant Bandaranaike was responsible for defence and foreign affairs.{{sfn|Skard|2015|p=151}} Though the office of prime minister had become mainly a ceremonial post, Bandaranaike's influence in the Freedom Party remained strong.{{sfn|''BBC''|2000a}} While they agreed on policy, Kumaratunga and Bandaranaike differed on leadership style. By 2000, Kumaratunga wanted a younger prime minister,{{sfn|''BBC''|2000b}} and Bandaranaike, citing health reasons, stepped down in August 2000.{{sfn|Ganguly|2000}} ==Death and legacy== [[File:Bandaranaike Samadhi at Horagolla, Sri Lanka.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Bandaranaike Samadhi (where S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike and Sirimavo Bandaranaike were entombed) at Horagolla, Sri Lanka]] Bandaranaike died on 10 October 2000 of a heart attack at [[Kadawatha]], as she was heading home to Colombo.{{sfn|Kirinde|2000}} She had been casting her vote in the [[Sri Lankan parliamentary election, 2000|parliamentary election]], which had been held that day.{{sfn|''BBC''|2000b}} Sri Lanka declared two days of national mourning, and state radio stations abandoned their regular programming to play funereal laments.{{sfn|Dugger|2000}} Bandaranaike's remains lay in state in the parliament, and her funeral subsequently took place at [[Horagolla Walauwa|Horagolla]] where she was interned in the mausoleum, [[Horagolla Bandaranaike Samadhi]], originally built for her husband.{{sfn|Nakkawita|2010}} At a time when there were few options open to women beyond the conventional role of wife and mother,{{sfn|''The Sunday Times''|2016}} she helped raise the global perception of women's capabilities.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}} In addition to her own contributions to Sri Lanka, her children became involved in the development of the country. All three children held nationally prominent positions; in addition to Anura and Chandrika's roles in government,{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}}{{sfn|Dahlburg|1994|p=4}}{{sfn|Jeyaraj|2017}} her daughter Sunetra worked as her mother's political secretary in the 1970s and later became a noted philanthropist.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}}{{sfn|''The Los Angeles Times''|2000}} The Bandaranaike marriage helped break down [[Caste system in Sri Lanka|social barriers]] in Sri Lanka over the years,{{sfn|Rettie|2000}}{{sfn|''The Daily Telegraph''|2000}} through the [[Socialism|Socialist policies]] they enacted.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=125}}{{sfn|Riswan|2014|p=42}} During her three terms in office, Bandaranaike led the country to break free of its colonial past, forming a republic. Implementing socialist policies during the [[Cold War]], she attempted to nationalize key sectors of the economy and undertake land reforms to benefit the native population,{{sfn|''The Los Angeles Times''|2000}} desiring to end the political favouratism enjoyed by the Western-educated elites.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}} An overriding goal of her policies was to reduce the ethnic and socio-economic disparities in the country,{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=272}} though her failure to address adequately the needs of the Tamil population led to decades of strife and violence in the country.{{sfn|Saha|1999|p=126}} As one of the founders of the Non-Aligned Movement,{{sfn|''The Los Angeles Times''|2000}} Bandaranaike navigated the divided world stage and successfully brought Sri Lanka to prominence among those nations which strove to remain neutral to the influence of the superpowers.{{sfn|Richardson|2005|pp=303–306}} As an agent of peace, she strove to forge lasting alliances between the countries in the [[Global South]]{{sfn||''The Sunday Times''|2016}} and worked closely with world leaders to resolve issues diplomatically, opposing nuclear expansion.{{sfn|Kodikara|1973|p=1128}}{{sfn|Phadnis|1971|p=272}} In 2010, on the 50th anniversary of Bandaranaike's election as the world's first female prime minister, former president Chandrika Kumarathunga criticized the Sri Lankan government for failing to recognize her mother's legacy. [[Rosy Senanayake]], an opposition MP, told the press that gender equality in Sri Lankan politics had not made significant strides, despite Bandaranaike's early rise to power; only 4.5 per cent of parliamentarians were women. Senanayake had earlier called for a "special quota" to achieve better gender representation.{{sfn|''BBC News''|2010}} By 2017, only 5.7 per cent of parliamentary positions and 1.9 per cent of local offices were held by women.{{sfn|''NewsIn.Asia''|2017}} A 2016 bill was passed that reserved 25 per cent of all local electoral seats for women, with the additional aim of making it more feasible for women to run for higher political positions. In February 2018, local elections saw a record-breaking 17,000 women run for office across the country.{{sfn|Sala|Lahiri|2018}} ==See also== *[[List of political families in Sri Lanka]] *[[Bandaranaike family]] ==Notes== {{NoteFoot}} ==References== ===Citations=== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin|30em}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Alexander |first=Robert Jackson |title=International Trotskyism, 1929–1985: A Documented Analysis of the Movement |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_eUtQjseKaIC&pg=PA180 |date=1991 |publisher=[[Duke University Press]] |location=Durham, North Carolina |isbn=0-8223-1066-X}} *{{cite news |ref=harv |last1=Ashborn |first1=Francis |title=Sri Lankans braced for political violence |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/25109649/the_guardian/ |accessdate=4 November 2018 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=14 October 1980 |page=7 |location=London, England |via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}} *{{cite book |ref=harv |last=Ayivan |first=Vikṭar |title=The Queen of Deceit |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TTRuAAAAMAAJ |date=2007 |publisher=Ravaya Publishers |location=Maharagama, Sri Lanka |isbn=978-955-1468-04-0}} *{{cite news |ref=harv |last1=Balachandran |first1=P. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} [[File:Sir Squire Bancroft.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Squire Bancroft]] '''Sir Squire Bancroft''' (14 May 1841 – 19 April 1926), born '''Squire White Butterfield''', was an English [[actor-manager]]. He and his wife [[Effie Bancroft]] are considered to have instigated a new form of drama known as 'drawing-room comedy' or 'cup and saucer drama', owing to the realism of their stage sets.
==Early life and career== Bancroft was born in [[Rotherhithe]], London. His first appearance on the stage was in 1861 at [[Birmingham]], and he played in the provinces with success for several years. His first London appearance was in 1865 as Jack Crawley in J. P. Wooler's ''A Winning Hazard'' at the [[Scala Theatre|Prince of Wales's Theatre]] off [[Tottenham Court Road]]. This theatre was managed by [[Henry James Byron|Henry Byron]] and [[Effie Bancroft|Effie Marie Wilton]], whom Bancroft married in December 1867. After their marriage the couple became joint managers of the theatre.
Mr and Mrs Bancroft produced and starred in all the [[Thomas William Robertson]] comedies beginning in 1865: ''[[Society (play)|Society]]'' (1865), ''Ours'' (1866), ''[[Caste (play)|Caste]]'' (1867), ''Play'' (1868), ''School'' (1869) and ''M.P.'' (1870), and, after Robertson's death, in revivals of the old comedies, for which they surrounded themselves with an admired company. Together, Robertson and the Bancrofts are considered to have instigated a new form of drama known as "drawing-room comedy" or "cup and saucer drama". The Bancrofts gave Robertson an unprecedented amount of directorial control over his plays, which was a key step to institutionalizing the power that directors wield in the theatre today.<ref>[http://faculty.winthrop.edu/vorderbruegg/winthropweb/vitaindex/gilbert.html Vorder Bruegge, Andrew "W. S. Gilbert: Antiquarian Authenticity and Artistic Autocracy" (Associate Professor, Department Chair, Department of Theatre and Dance, Winthrop University). Professor Vorder Bruegge presented this paper at the Victorian Interdisciplinary Studies Association of the Western United States annual conference in October 2002] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5yPic5kyJ?url=http://faculty.winthrop.edu/vorderbruegg/winthropweb/vitaindex/gilbert.html |date=3 May 2011 }}, accessed 26 March 2008</ref>
The Bancroft management at the Prince of Wales's Theatre constituted a new era in the development of the English stage and had the effect of reviving the London interest in modern drama. They were also responsible for making fashionable the "box set", which [[Lucia Elizabeth Vestris]] had first used at the [[Olympic Theatre]] in the 1830s – this consisted of rooms on stage which were dressed with sofas, curtains, chairs, and carpets on the stage floor. They also provided their actors with salaries and wardrobes. Also, the Bancrofts redesigned their theatre to suit the increasingly upscale audience: "The cheap benches near the stage, where the rowdiest elements of the audience used to sit were replaced by comfortable padded seats, carpets were laid in the aisles, and the pit was renamed the stalls."<ref>[http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/drama_tour/19th_century/cup.php Information about Cup and Saucer realism] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070416042300/http://www.peopleplayuk.org.uk/guided_tours/drama_tour/19th_century/cup.php |date=16 April 2007 }} (PeoplePlay UK)</ref>
Other plays they premiered or produced there were [[W. S. Gilbert]]'s ''Allow Me To Explain'' (1867) and his romantic comedy tribute to Robertson, ''[[Sweethearts (play)|Sweethearts]]'' (1874), as well as ''Tame Cats'' (1868), [[Edward Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton|Lytton's]] ''Money'' (1872), ''[[The School for Scandal]]'' (1874), [[Dion Boucicault|Boucicault's]] ''London Assurance'' (1877), and ''Diplomacy'' (1878), an adaptation of [[Victorien Sardou|Sardou]]'s ''Dora'' by [[Clement Scott]] and [[B. C. Stephenson]].
[[File:SquireBancroftBrompton01.jpg|thumb|right|Funerary monument, Brompton Cemetery, London]]
==Later life and career== In the 1870s and 1880s, in addition to his management responsibilities, Bancroft continued to play leading roles in numerous contemporary plays, as well as in works by Shakespeare and [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan]]'s and other classic plays, often opposite his wife.<ref name=NYPL>[http://archives.nypl.org/the/21493 "Squire Bancroft letter book, 1836-1922"], Billy Rose Theatre Division, [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]], accessed 8 December 2013</ref> In 1879, the Bancrofts moved to the [[Haymarket Theatre]], where they produced or starred in a revival of ''Money'', and in Sardou's ''Odette'' (for which they engaged Madame [[Helena Modjeska]]), ''Fedora'', and Pinero's ''Lords and Commons'', with revivals of previous successes.
Having made a considerable fortune, they retired from management in 1885, but Bancroft continued to act until 1918.<ref name=NYPL/> Bancroft was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in 1897. Between 1917, and his death in 1926, Bancroft maintained rooms at the fashionable [[Albany (London)|Albany]], in [[Piccadilly]].<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=41481 ''Albany'', Survey of London: volumes 31 and 32: St James Westminster, Part 2 (1963), pp. 367-389] accessed: 5 November 2007</ref> Both he and his wife are buried in [[Brompton Cemetery]].<ref>{{Find a Grave|12407}}</ref>
==Publications== Bancroft wrote two books, and in collaboration with his wife, he wrote two volumes of reminiscences called ''Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft On and Off the Stage, Written by Themselves'' (London, 1888) and ''The Bancrofts: Recollections of Sixty Years'' (London: Dutton and Co., 1909).
