[[Willem Witteveen]] (second cousin) | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20160116194944/http://www.theovangogh.nl/ Official site] | footnotes = | box_width = }} {{Criticism of Islam sidebar}} '''Theodoor''' "'''Theo'''" '''van Gogh''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈteːjoː vɑŋ ˈɣɔx|lang}};''Van'' in isolation: {{IPA-nl|vɑn|}}. 23 July 1957 – 2 November 2004) was a Dutch film director, film producer, television director, television producer, television presenter, screenwriter, actor, critic and author. Van Gogh worked with the [[Somalia|Somali]]-born writer and politician [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]] to produce the short film ''[[Submission (2004 film)|Submission]]'' (2004), which criticized the treatment of [[women in Islam]]. It provoked outrage from the Dutch Muslim community. On 2 November 2004, van Gogh was assassinated by [[Mohammed Bouyeri]], a [[Islam in the Netherlands|Dutch-Moroccan Muslim]] who objected to the controversial film. The last film van Gogh had completed before his death, ''[[06/05]]'', was a fictionalized exploration of the assassination of Dutch politician [[Pim Fortuyn]] (1948–2002). It was released posthumously in December 2004, a month following van Gogh's assassination. ==Early life== Theo van Gogh was born on 23 July 1957 in [[The Hague]], Netherlands, to Anneke and Johan van Gogh. His father served in the Dutch secret service ('[[AIVD]]', then called 'BVD'). He was named after his paternal uncle Theo, who was captured and executed while working as a [[Resistance during World War II|resistance]] fighter during the [[Nazi]] occupation of the Netherlands during [[World War II]].{{cite book|last1=Butter|first1=Jan-Cees|last2=Houtman|first2=Joost|year=2013|title=De foute ster: Moord en doodslag in de showbusiness|trans-title=The Faulty Star: Murder and Manslaughter in Show Business|url={{Google books|eqkH3OjhFdQC|De foute ster: Moord en doodslag in de showbusiness|page=117|plainurl=yes}}|language=Dutch|publisher=Lebowski Publishers|isbn=9789048816989|accessdate=2 November 2014}} Theo van Gogh was a great-grandson of [[Theo van Gogh (art dealer)|Theo van Gogh]], art dealer and brother of painter [[Vincent van Gogh]]. ==Career== After dropping out of law school at the [[University of Amsterdam]], van Gogh became a [[Stage management|stage manager]]. His self-proclaimed passion was film-making, and he made his debut as a director with the movie ''Luger'' (1981). He was awarded a ''[[Gouden Kalf]]'' for ''Blind Date'' (1996) and ''In het belang van de staat'' ("In the Interest of the State," 1997). For the latter, he also received a "Certificate of Merit" from the [[San Francisco International Film Festival]]. As an actor, he appeared in the film, ''De noorderlingen'' ("The Northerners", 1992). He made numerous films (see below), many on political themes. From the 1990s, van Gogh also worked in television. His last book (2003) was ''Allah weet het beter''{{cite book|last1=Van Gogh|first1=Theo|title=Allah Weet het Niet Beter|date=2003|isbn=9789050561112}} ("[[Allah]] Knows Best"), in which he strongly condemned [[Islam]]. He was a well-known critic of Islam, particularly after the [[Iranian Revolution]] and the [[September 11 attacks]]. He supported the nomination of writer [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]] for the [[Dutch parliament]], who was elected. Born in [[Somalia]], she had immigrated to the Netherlands to escape an arranged marriage. She became a writer and [[liberalism|liberal]] (former PvdA [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]]) [[politician]]. In the 1980s, van Gogh became a newspaper columnist. Through the years he used his columns to express his frustration with politicians, actors, film directors, writers and other people he considered to be part of "the establishment". He delighted in provocation and became a controversial figure, frequently criticizing Islamic cultures. He used his website, ''De Gezonde Roker'' ("The Healthy Smoker"), to express harsh [[Criticism of multiculturalism|criticism of multicultural society]]. He said the Netherlands was so rife with social turmoil that it was in danger of turning into "something [[Belfast#The Troubles|Belfast]]-like".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/theo-van-gogh-749703.html|title=Theo van Gogh – Controversial film-maker|publisher=The Independent|date=4 November 2004|accessdate=29 April 2010|location=London}} ===''Submission''=== Working from a script written by Ayaan Hirsi Ali, van Gogh created the 10-minute short film ''[[Submission (2004 film)|Submission]]''. The movie deals with [[violence against women]] in some Islamic societies; it tells the stories, using visual shock tactics, of four abused Muslim women. The title, ''Submission'', is a translation of the word "[[Islam#Etymology and meaning|Islam]]" into English. In the film, women's naked bodies, with texts from the [[Qur'an]] written on them in henna, in an allusion to traditional wedding rituals in some cultures, are veiled with semi-transparent shrouds as the women kneel in prayer, telling their stories as if they are speaking to Allah. In August 2004, after the movie's broadcast on Dutch public TV, the newspaper ''De Volkskrant'' reported that the journalist Francisco van Jole had accused Hirsi Ali and van Gogh of plagiarism, saying that they had appropriated the ideas of [[Iran]]ian-American [[video]] artist [[Shirin Neshat]], whose work used Arabic text projected onto bodies.{{cite news|last1=Groen|first1=Janny|date=1 September 2004|title=Hirsi Ali en van Gogh van plagiaat beticht|trans-title=Hirsi Ali and van Gogh accused of plagiarism|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article184995.ece/Hirsi_Ali_en_Van_Gogh_van_plagiaat_beticht|newspaper=[[de Volkskrant]]|language=Dutch|publisher=De Persgroep Nederland|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071017012506/http://www.volkskrant.nl/binnenland/article184995.ece/Hirsi_Ali_en_Van_Gogh_van_plagiaat_beticht|archivedate=17 October 2007|accessdate=2 November 2014}} Following the broadcast, both van Gogh and Hirsi Ali received [[death threat]]s. Van Gogh did not take the threats seriously and refused any protection. According to Hirsi Ali, he said, "Nobody kills the [[village idiot]]", a term he frequently used about himself.{{cite book|author=[[Ayaan Hirsi Ali|Hirsi Ali, Ayaan]]|title=Infidel|date=2007|page=314}} ==Personal life== Van Gogh was a member of the Dutch [[republicanism|Republican]] society ''[[Republikeins Genootschap]]'', which advocates the [[abolition of monarchy|abolition]] of the [[Dutch monarchy]]. He was a friend and supporter of the controversial Dutch politician [[Pim Fortuyn]],{{Cite book|last=Eyerman|first=Ron|year=2011|chapter=The Murder of Van Gogh|title=The Cultural Sociology of Political Assassination: From MLK and RFK to Fortuyn and van Gogh|chapter-url={{Google books|aa1hAQAAQBAJ|The Cultural Sociology of Political Assassination|page=164|plainurl=yes}}|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=9780230118232|accessdate=2 November 2014}} who was [[assassinated]] in 2002.{{cite news|last=Simons|first=Marlise|author-link=Marlise Simons|date=7 May 2002|title=Rightist in Netherlands Is Slain, and the Nation Is Stunned|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/07/international/europe/07DUTC.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|location=[[The Hague]]|accessdate=2 November 2014}} ==Murder== [[File:Plaats waar Theo van Gogh vermoord is.jpg|thumb|Place where van Gogh was killed.]] [[File:P1020978 bullet holes Mohammed Bouyeri - Theo van Gogh.jpg|thumb|Ten years after the murder, the bullet holes were still visible in the bicycle lane in front of Linnaeusstraat 22 (picture taken 2 November 2014).]] [[File:Theo van Gogh - Protesten op de Dam.jpg|thumb|Demonstration at the Dam square after van Gogh was killed.]] [[File:Theo van Gogh - Protesten op de Dam 2.jpg|thumb|Demonstrators. The sign, translated, says "Theo has been murdered".]] Van Gogh was shot and stabbed by [[Mohammed Bouyeri]] while cycling to work on 2 November 2004 at about 9 o'clock in the morning. Bouyeri also injured some bystanders and left on the scene a note containing death threats to [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], who went into hiding. It also threatened Western countries and [[Jew]]s, and referred to ideologies of the [[Egypt]]ian organization [[Takfir wal-Hijra]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/controversial-filmmaker-shot-dead-18345.html|title=Controversial filmmaker shot dead|publisher=''The Independent''|date=2 November 2004|accessdate=29 April 2010|location=London}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/ayaan-hirsi-ali-my-life-under-a-fatwa-760666.html |title=Ayaan Hirsi Ali: My life under a fatwa|publisher=The Independent|date=27 November 2007|accessdate=29 April 2010|location=London}} Bouyeri, a 26-year-old Dutch-Moroccan citizen, was apprehended by police after a chase. Authorities alleged that he had [[terrorism|terrorist]] ties with the Dutch Islamist [[Hofstad Network]]. He was charged with the [[attempted murder]] of several police officers and bystanders, illegal possession of a firearm, and conspiring to murder others, including Hirsi Ali. He was convicted at trial on 26 July 2005 and sentenced to [[life in prison]] with no chance of [[parole]].[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/netherlands/1494918/Life-for-van-Gogh-killer-fails-to-ease-Dutch-fears.html "Life for van Gogh killer fails to ease Dutch fears"] The murder sparked outrage and grief throughout the Netherlands. Flowers, notes, drawings and other expressions of mourning were left at the scene of the murder.[http://stadsarchief.amsterdam.nl/english/amsterdam_treasures/death/theo_van_gogh/index.en.html Expressions of mourning for Theo van Gogh]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, kept at the Amsterdam City Archives ===Funeral=== The [[cremation]] ceremony took place on 9 November. Fearing he might not survive a planned flight to New York, Van Gogh had spoken about his funeral wishes with friends shortly before his death.{{Cite web |url=http://www.novatv.nl/page/detail/uitzendingen/3013#|title=De crematie van Theo van Gogh|publisher=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]|date=9 November 2004|accessdate=17 July 2012 |language=Dutch}} [[Maarten van Rossem]] was asked by Van Gogh's relatives to speak, something he found difficult in that he wanted to avoid sounding apocalyptic.{{Cite web |url=http://www.maartenonline.nl/Maarten-van-Rossem/index.html|language=Dutch|title=Biografie Maarten van Rossem|accessdate=17 July 2012}} Van Gogh's father suggested that his son would have liked the media attention provoked by his murder. === Aftermath === The day after the murder, Dutch police arrested eight people allegedly belonging to a group later referred to as the [[Hofstad Network]]. Six detainees were Dutch-[[Moroccan people|Moroccans]], one was Dutch-[[Algerian people|Algerian]], and one had dual [[Spanish people|Spanish]]-Moroccan nationality. The Dutch Complaints Bureau for Discrimination on the Internet (MDI) received many complaints about websites allegedly praising the murder and making death threats against other people.{{ref|eumc1}} At the same time, starting with four attempted [[arson]] attacks on [[mosque]]s in the weekend of 5–7 November, there were retaliatory violent incidents against Muslims,{{ref|brabdag}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/bombing-of-muslim-school-linked-to-murder-of-filmmaker-532551.html |title=Bombing of Muslim school linked to murder of film-maker|publisher=The Independent|date=9 November 2004|accessdate=29 April 2010|location=London|first=Stephen|last=Castle}} including a bomb that exploded at a Muslim school in [[Eindhoven]].{{cite web | url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/international_papers/2004/11/holland_in_flames.html?via=gdpr-consent | title=Holland in flames| date=2004-11-11}} The Dutch Monitoring Centre on Racism and Xenophobia recorded a total of 106 violent incidents in November against Muslim targets. The National Dutch Police Services Agency (KLPD) recorded 31 occasions of violence against mosques and Islamic schools between 23 November and 13 March 2005.{{ref|eumc2}} An arson attack destroyed a Muslim primary school in [[Uden]] in December 2004.{{ref|eumap}} By 8 November, [[Christian]] churches were reported as targets of vandalism and arson attacks in turn. A report for the [[Anne Frank Foundation]] and the [[University of Leiden]], accounted for a total of 174 violent incidents between 2–30 November; it said that mosques were the target of violence 47 times, and churches 13 times.{{ref|frank}} The murder widened and polarized the debate in the Netherlands about the social position of its more than one million [[Muslim]] residents. It also put the country's [[Liberalism|liberal]] tradition further into question, coming only two years after [[Pim Fortuyn]]'s murder. In an apparent reaction against controversial statements about the [[Islam]]ic, [[Christian]], and [[Jew]]ish religions—such as those van Gogh was renowned for—the Dutch Minister of Justice, [[Christian Democratic Appeal|Christian Democrat]] [[Piet Hein Donner]], suggested Dutch [[blasphemy]] laws should either be applied more stringently or made more strict. The liberal [[Democrats 66|D66]] party suggested scrapping the blasphemy laws altogether. [[File:De Schreeuw.jpg|thumb|upright|left|''[[De Schreeuw]]'' (The Scream) is a memorial for Theo van Gogh and a symbol of the [[freedom of speech]]]] [[Geert Wilders]], an Independent Dutch member of parliament, advocated a five-year halt to [[immigration]] from non-Western societies, saying: "The Netherlands has been too tolerant to intolerant people for too long. We should not import a retarded political Islamic society into our country".{{cite news|last1=Deutsch|first1=Anthony|date=20 November 2004|title=Netherlands Opposing Immigration|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-102633559.html|location=[[The Hague]]|publisher=[[HighBeam Research]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|accessdate=2 November 2014|registration=yes}} Wilders and [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]] went into hiding for several weeks. Wilders has been under the protection of bodyguards ever since, and Hirsi Ali eventually relocated to the United States. Theo van Gogh's son claims he has been attacked on several occasions by young people of [[Moroccan people|Moroccan]] and [[Turkish people|Turkish]] descent, and that the police did not provide him with help or protection.{{cite news|last1=Van Wonderen|first1=Mark|date=28 July 2005|title=Marokkanen slaan Lieuwe van Gogh in elkaar|trans-title=Moroccans beat up Lieuwe van Gogh|url=http://www.planet.nl/planet/show/id=62967/contentid=603229/sc=1437d8|language=Dutch|publisher=[[Planet Internet]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616041121/http://www.planet.nl/planet/show/id=62967/contentid=603229/sc=1437d8|archivedate=16 June 2008|accessdate=2 November 2014}} The police denied receiving any report of attacks.{{cite news|date=28 July 2005|title='Lieuwe van Gogh niet mishandeld'|trans-title='Lieuwe van Gogh not abused'|url=http://www.parool.nl/nieuws/2005/JUL/28/p5.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203051735/http://www.parool.nl/nieuws/2005/JUL/28/p5.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=3 February 2017|newspaper=[[Het Parool]]|language=Dutch|location=[[Amsterdam]]|publisher=De Persgroep Nederland|agency=[[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau|ANP]]|accessdate=2 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elsevier.nl/nieuws/nederland/nieuwsbericht/asp/artnr/56876/index.html|title=Politie ontkent nalatigheid zaak zoon Van Gogh|publisher=Elsevier|accessdate=2012-02-14|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060101124421/http://www.elsevier.nl/nieuws/nederland/nieuwsbericht/asp/artnr/56876/index.html|archivedate=1 January 2006|df=dmy-all}} ==Legacy and honors== *On 18 March 2007, a [[sculpture]] honoring Theo van Gogh, entitled ''[[De Schreeuw]]'' ("The Scream"), was unveiled in [[Amsterdam]]. It is located in the [[Oosterpark (Amsterdam)|Oosterpark]], a short distance from where van Gogh was murdered.{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/news/1011872/10/Monument_Theo_van_Gogh_onthuld_%28video%29.html|title=Monument Theo van Gogh onthuld (video)|publisher=Nu.nl|accessdate=14 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080929170512/http://www.nu.nl/news/1011872/10/Monument_Theo_van_Gogh_onthuld_(video).html|archivedate=29 September 2008|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hansteeuwen.net/index.ht/content/artikel_8|title=Full text of speech by Hans Teeuwen|publisher=Hansteeuwen|date=22 October 2006|accessdate=29 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oost-watergraafsmeer.nl/nieuws_en/nieuws_0?ActItmIdt=47002|title=page about De Schreeuw on the website of Stadsdeel Oost/Watergraafsmeer|date=29 May 2007|publisher=[[Government of Amsterdam]] ([[Oost-Watergraafsmeer]])|language=Dutch|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928002637/http://www.oost-watergraafsmeer.nl/nieuws_en/nieuws_0?ActItmIdt=47002|archivedate=28 September 2007|accessdate=2 November 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/news/1236796/13/Monument_Theo_van_Gogh_beklad_met_zwarte_stift.html|title=Monument Theo van Gogh beklad met zwarte stift|publisher=Nu.nl|accessdate=14 February 2012}} *A private trust, the [[Foundation for Freedom of Expression]], was established to help fund protection for critics of Islam and Muslims.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/264049|title=Dutch labour party ends political correctness|publisher=''Digital Journal''|accessdate=29 April 2010}} ===Reactions=== In the English-speaking world, controversy arose after [[Rohan Jayasekera (writer)|Rohan Jayasekera]]'s article on van Gogh was published in ''[[Index on Censorship]]''. The Associate Editor of the magazine said that van Gogh was a "free-speech fundamentalist" who had been on a "[[martyrdom]] operation[,] roar[ing] his Muslim critics into silence with obscenities" in an "abuse of his right to free speech". Describing van Gogh's film ''Submission'' as "furiously provocative", Jayasekera said his death was: {{quote|A sensational climax to a lifetime's public performance, stabbed and shot by a bearded fundamentalist, a message from the killer pinned by a dagger to his chest, Theo van Gogh became a martyr to free expression. His passing was marked by a magnificent barrage of noise as Amsterdam hit the streets to celebrate him in the way the man himself would have truly appreciated. And what timing! Just as his long-awaited biographical film of [[Pim Fortuyn]]'s life is ready to screen. Bravo, Theo! Bravo!{{ref|bio}}}} Both left- and right-wing commentators criticized the article. In December 2004, [[Nick Cohen]] of London's ''[[The Observer|Observer]]'' wrote: {{quote|When I asked Jayasekera if he had any regrets, he said he had none. He told me that, like many other readers, I shouldn't have made the mistake of believing that ''Index on Censorship'' was against [[censorship]], even murderous censorship, on principle – in the same way as [[Amnesty International]] is opposed to [[torture]], including murderous torture, on principle. It may have been so in its radical youth, but was now as concerned with fighting '[[hate speech]]' as protecting free speech.{{ref|hatespeech}}}} Cohen's account of the conversation was repudiated by the editor of the ''Index on Censorship'', who responded with a letter to ''[[The Observer]]''.{{ref|censor}} ==Works== ===Books=== * ''Engel'' ("Angel", 1990) * ''Er gebeurt nooit iets'' ("Nothing Ever Happens", 1993) * ''Sla ik mijn vrouw wel hard genoeg?'' {{Infobox person | name = William Baume | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1885 | birth_place = [[Les Bois]], Switzerland | death_date = {{Death year and age|1956|1885}} | death_place = [[Geneva]], Switzerland | nationality = Swiss | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = co-founder of [[Baume et Mercier]] }} '''William Baume''' (1885–1956) was a [[Swiss]] watchmaker who established the [[Baume et Mercier|Baume & Mercier]] company in Geneva in 1918 with his partner, Paul Mercier.
==Early life and family== William Baume was born into a notable family of [[watchmaker]]s in the village of [[Les Bois]] in the [[Swiss Jura]]. His grandfather, Louis Victor Baume, and his great-uncle, Célestin Baume had founded the Frères Baume watch dealership in Les Bois in 1830. It was to become one of Switzerland’s major watch manufacturers in the 19th century, with branches in London, Geneva and Philadelphia. The Baume watch brand won distinctions at the [[World's fair|universal expositions]] between 1860 and 1900, including a number of gold medals and Grand Prix for its watches. In 1892, its [[tourbillon]] [[Chronometer watch|chronometer]] set an absolute timekeeping record at the [[Kew Observatory]] trials that stood for 10 years.
==Management of Baume company== William Baume, who took over the management of the Baume company in Les Bois in 1910, represented the third generation after his grandfather and father. He had previously completed his watchmaking apprenticeship with [[Mathey-Tissot]] at [[Les Ponts-de-Martel]], about 30 kilometers from Les Bois between Le Locle and Neuchâtel. Mathey-Tissot, established in 1886, was specialised in complicated watches, especially [[Repeater (horology)|minute-repeaters]] and precision [[chronograph]]s. It was thus with this specialist background that William Baume joined the family firm in 1909, working for a year with his father until he was entrusted with the management of the company in 1910. William Baume had then just turned 25. Meanwhile the London branch of Frères Baume, run by William’s uncle, Arthur Baume, was playing a leading role in the affairs of the business. After a family row, William Baume left Les Bois in 1918, shortly after the end of World War I. He settled in Geneva with the intention of starting a watch company that would take over from the Baume firm.
==Partnership with Paul Mercier== In Geneva he came across his friend, Paul Mercier, whom he had met in 1912 as marketing manager of Haas of Geneva, one of the big names in Swiss watchmaking.
The two men joined forces to found Baume & Mercier in Geneva in 1918. Paul Mercier looked after the business side, while William Baume supervised the technical and watchmaking aspects. Their complementary talents ensured the quick success of the business, which relied on William Baume’s experience and the reputation of the Baume firm.
As an accomplished watchmaker and hard worker, William Baume was instrumental in qualifying Baume & Mercier watches in 1919 for the prestigious ''[[Geneva seal|Poinçon de Genève]]'', the hallmark of the best quality Geneva watchmaking.
William Baume’s watchmaking competence and Paul Mercier’s business acumen enabled Baume & Mercier to prosper during the economic crises of the late 1920s. In 1935, William Baume retired from the company for health reasons, and his sons had no interest in the business. Paul Mercier, retired two years later, selling his stake to the new partner, Ernesto Ponti, a businessman from the Piedmont who had acquired a stake in Baume & Mercier in 1934. William Baume died in Geneva in 1956.

{{EngvarB|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Úna Brennan | other_names = | image = Úna_Brennan.jpg
| imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Anastasia Bolger | birth_date = 1888 | birth_place = [[County Wexford]], Ireland | death_date = 1958 | death_place = Ireland | nationality = Irish }} '''Úna Brennan''' (1888–1958) was an Irish [[Irish republicanism|republican]] and feminist, active during the [[Easter Rising]] of 1916 and both the [[Irish War of Independence|War of Independence]] and [[Irish Civil War|Civil War]].
==Early life== Born Anastasia Bolger in 1888 to John Bolger and Johanna Whitty, she was the eldest of six children in Coolnaboy, [[County Wexford]].<ref name="Echo"/> She was educated in the Loreto Convent in [[Enniscorthy]], where she had to be a boarder living away from home.
In 1908 Brennan arranged to get a monthly column in ''The Echo'' newspaper edited by William Sears. She covered topics like Women's rights both in the home and in public life. She joined [[Inghinidhe na hÉireann]] and became the local Secretary, later she was a member of [[Cumann na mBan]]. She was also one of the first female members of the [[Irish Republican Brotherhood]].<ref name="Echo"/> As a supporter of the Irish Language Brennan initially changed her name to Anatás before changing it to Úna.<ref name="irishexaminer">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/seven-women-who-played-a-key-part-in-1916-and-beyond-impacting-on-society-383228.html|title=Seven women who played a key part in 1916 and beyond, impacting on society|author=Sinead McCoole}}</ref>
She married [[Robert Brennan (journalist)|Robert Brennan]] on July 6, 1909. He was in the [[Gaelic League]] and [[Sinn Féin]]. He taught Irish in Wexford, Tagoat, and Castlebridge. He was a member of the Irish Republican Brotherhood and insisted they swear his wife in as well. He believed only two women were sworn in, his wife and [[Maud Gonne]]. According to [[Helena Molony]] she was a significant influence in the magazine Bean na hÉireann.<ref name="irishexaminer"/>
==Irish Wars==
Despite having a six-year-old daughter at home she was with her husband in the Athenaeum in Enniscorthy, County Wexford during the Rising. She was one of three women who raised the [[Irish Flag|Tricolour]] on the building on Thursday, 27 April 1916<ref name="Echo">{{cite web|url=http://enniscorthy1916.ie/?page_id=277|title=County Wexford 1916:Una Brennan}}</ref> with [[Marion Stokes (ireland)|Marion Stokes]] and [[Gretta Comerford]]. She then set up an emergency hospital and kitchen which she ran for the duration of the occupation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wexford.ie/wex/Departments/Library/downloads/Thefile,26239,en.pdf|title=The 1916 Rising and County Wexford}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wexfordpeople.ie/news/wexford-women-of-the-1916-rising-31562229.html|title=Wexford women of the 1916 Rising}}</ref> Brennan was arrested and taken to gaol in [[Waterford]] and later to [[Mountjoy Prison]]. However she was released after a few days.<ref name="irishexaminer"/>
After the Rising the family moved to [[Dublin]]. Brennan was active in the [[Irish War of Independence]], using the home as a safe house for documents and men in hiding, such as [[Harry Boland]] and Colman O'Donovan. During the [[Irish Civil War]] they were on the Anti-Treaty side and continued to shelter men, documents and dispatches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishmedals.org/enniscorthy.html|title=Enniscorthy County Wexford}}</ref>
She and her husband had three daughters, Emer, Maeve and Derry (Deirdre), as well as a son, Robert Patrick. [[Maeve Brennan]] became a well known writer.<ref name="irishexaminer"/> Robert Brennan was involved in politics and was sent to the USA. However the couple returned to Ireland in 1947. They lived in Rathfarnham, Dublin once Robert Brennan was Director of Broadcasting at Radio Éireann. Úna Brennan died in 1958.<ref name="RBrennan">{{cite web|url=http://www.yvonnejerrold.com/RBrennan/Robert%20Brennan%201881-1964.html|title=Robert Brennan 1881-1964}}</ref>
